case_data.name: Rollins v. Clatsop County
case_data.plaintiff_description: All persons charged with misdemeanors or minor crimes and strip searched upon their entry into the Clatsop County Jail.
case_data.summary:
On November 8, 2007, the plaintiff brought a complaint against the Clatsop County Jail and Clatsop County, on behalf of himself and thousands of others pursuant to 42 U.S.C. §1983, in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon. The complaint challenged the jail's policy of strip-searching all individuals entering the county jail and then placing them in jail clothing. Represented by private counsel, the plaintiff asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief. The plaintiff contended that all people, even those convicted of minor crimes and misdemeanors, were strip-searched upon their entry into the jail.

Judge Garr M. King granted plaintiff's motion for leave to file an amended complaint on September 18, 2008. The amended complaint joined six new plaintiffs to the action who had all been stripped and cavity-searched.

Discovery continued until January 26, 2009. During that time, the plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed all but two of the plaintiffs.

On February 27, 2009, the defendants moved for summary judgment. The defense argued that the searches were constitutional because the plaintiffs met established criteria for strip searches and the defendant officer was shielded by qualified immunity.

On May 5, 2009, Judge King entered summary judgment for the defendants. We are not able to obtain a copy of the order entering summary judgment.
case_data.summary_short: An Oregon plaintiff brought a class action suit against an officer and the county, claiming the county was conducting illegal strip and cavity searches for misdemeanor offenses. After all but two plaintiffs left the case voluntarily, the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon granted summary judgment for the defendants.

documents.title: Class Action Complaint
documents.text:
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE DISTFUCT OF OREGON 
DARRELL ROLLINS, 
both individually and on behalf of a class of : 
others similarly situated, 
Plaintiffs, 
Civil Action Number 
v. 
CLATSOP COUNTY, 
TOM BERGIN, 
both individually and in his 
official capacity as Sheriff, 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT 
JURY TRIAL DEMANDED 
Defendants. 
INTRODUCTION 
This is a class action brought to redress the deprivation by Defendants of rights secured 
to the Plaintiffs and proposed Class by the United States Constitution and the laws of the United 
States of America.  For at least the past several years, the Clatsop County Sheriffs Department 
has had a policy of strip-searching all individuals who enter the Clatsop County Jail and are 
placed in jail clothing, regardless of the crime upon which they are charged.  Upon information 
and belief, this policy is, in part, derived from the written procedures of the Clatsop County 
Sheriffs  Department,  and  was  promulgated  by  senior  Department  officials;  specifically, 
Defendant Tom Bergin. 
It has been well established in this judicial circuit for many years that individuals charged 
with misdemeanors or violations cannot be strip-searched absent particularized suspicion that 
they possess weapons or contraband.  In fact, several judges in this Judicial District, as well as 

the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, have recently held that blanket strip 
search policies/practices like those in dispute in this case are unconstitutional.  In short, the 
policy of Clatsop County and the Clatsop County Sheriffs Department of forcing those charged 
with minor crimes to undergo the indignities of a strip search upon entry into the Clatsop County 
Jail is not only clearly illegal, but is degrading, insensitive and unnecessary. 
Darrell  Rollins brings this  action on behalf  of himself, and on behalf  of a class of 
thousands of others who were strip searched after being charged with petty crimes, to vindicate 
the clear and unnecessary violation of his civil rights and those of the class members he proposes 
to  represent.  Mr.  Rollins was taken  in  on allegations of  Resisting Arrest.  Mr. Rollins was 
transported to the Clatsop County Jail and was subjected to a strip search, in violation of his right 
against unreasonable searches under the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution. 
He seeks monetary damages for himself and each member of the proposed class, a declaration 
that  the  Sheriffs  Department's  policies/practices  are  unconstitutional,  and  an  injunction 
precluding Clatsop County and the Clatsop County Sheriffs Department from continuing to 
violate the rights of those placed into their custody.  With this as a background, Plaintiff Darrell 
Rollins, through counsel, hereby complains as follows: 
JURISDICTION 
1.  This Court has jurisdiction  over this action under the provisions of 28 U.S.C.  $5 
133 1, 1341 & 1343 because it is filed to obtain compensatory damages, punitive damages, and 
injunctive relief for the deprivation, under color of state law, of the rights of citizens of the 
United States secured by the Constitution and federal law pursuant to 42 U.S.C. 55 1981 & 1983. 
This Court also has jurisdiction over this action under the provisions of 28 U.S.C. 8 2201, as it is 

filed  to  obtain  declaratory  relief  relative  to  the Constitutionality of the policies  of  a  local 
government. 
2.  Venue  is proper  under 28 U.S.C.  8  1391(e)(2) because the events giving rise to 
Plaintiff's claims and those of proposed class members occurred in this judicial district. 
PARTIES 
3.  Plaintiff Darrell Rollins ("Rollins")  resides in Wahkiakum County, Washington.  On 
or  about. November  20,  2005,  he was housed  at the  Clatsop  County Jail  for  allegation  of 
Resisting Arrest. 
4.  Defendant Clatsop County (the "County")  is a county government organized and 
existing under the laws of the State of Oregon.  At all times relevant hereto, the County, acting 
through  its  Sheriffs  Department,  was  responsible  for  the  policies,  practices,  supervision, 
implementation  and  conduct  of  all matters  pertaining  to  the  Clatsop  County  Jail  and  was 
responsible for the appointment, training, supervision and conduct of all Sheriffs Department 
personnel. including those working in the Clatsop County Jail.  In addition, at all relevant times, 
the County was responsible for enforcing the rules of the Clatsop County Jail, and for ensuring 
that Sheriffs Department personnel employed in the Jail obey the Constitution and laws of the 
United States and of the State of Oregon. 
5.  The Clatsop County Sheriffs Department (the "Sheriffs Department")  is a County 
Sheriffs Department organized and existing under the laws of the State of Oregon. At all times 
relevant hereto, the Sheriffs Department was responsible for operating, organizing, overseeing 
and administering the Clatsop County Jail ("CTCJ").  At all times relevant hereto, Defendant 
Sheriff  Department, together with Clatsop County was responsible for the polices, practices, 
:j 

supervision,  implementation and  conduct  of  all  matters  pertaining  to  the  CTCJ,  and  was 
responsilble for the appointment, training, supervision and conduct of all Sheriffs Department 
personnel, including those  working in the  CTCJ.  In addition, at all times relevant hereto, 
Defendant Sheriffs Department, together with Clatsop County, was responsible for enforcing 
the  rules of the  Clatsop County Jail, and  for ensuring that  Sheriffs Department personnel 
employed in the CTCJ obeyed the Constitution and laws of the United States and of the State of 
Oregon. 
61.  Defendant Tom Bergin is the duly elected Sheriff of Clatsop County, and, as such, is 
a policy maker with respect to the treatment of pre-trial and other detainees over which the CTCJ 
exercises custodial or other control. Sheriff Bergin is made a Defendant in this action in both his 
individual and official capacities. 
7.  Sheriff Bergin will be referred to as the "Policy Making Defendant." 

CLASS ACTION ALLEGATIONS 
8.  Plaintiff brings this action pursuant to Rules 23(b)(l), 23(b)(2) and 23(b)(3) of the 
Federal Rules of  Civil Procedure on behalf of themselves and a class of similarly  situated 
individuials who were charged with misdemeanors or minor crimes and were strip searched upon 
their entry into the Clatsop County Jail. 
9.  The class that Plaintiff seeks to represent is defined as follows: 
All persons who have been or will be placed into the custody of the Clatsop 
County Jail after being charged with misdemeanors, violations, violations of 
probation or parole, traffic infractions, civil commitments or other minor 
crimes and were or will be strip searched upon their entry into the Clatsop 
County  Jail pursuant to  the policy,  custom and practice  of the  Clatsop 
County  Sheriffs  Department  and  Clatsop  County.  The  class  period 
commences on November 8, 2005 and extends to the date on which the 
Clatsop  County  Sheriffs Department and/or  the  County of  Clatsop  are 
enjoined from, or otherwise cease, enforcing their unconstitutional policy, 
practice  and  custom  of  conducting  strip  searches  absent  reasonable 
suspicion.  Specifically excluded from the class are Defendants and any and 
all  of  their  respective  affiliates,  legal representatives,  heirs,  successors, 
employees or assignees. 
10. This action has been brought and may properly be maintained as a class action under 
Federal law and satisfies the numerosity, commonality, typicality and adequacy requirements for 
maintaining a class action under Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a). 
1 I. The members of the class are so numerous as to render joinder impracticable.  Upon 
information and belief, there are hundreds of people arrested for misdemeanors and violations 
who are placed into the custody of the Clatsop County Jail every month  all of whom are 
- 
members of the proposed class.  Upon information and belief, the size of the proposed class 
totals at least 1,000 individuals, some of whom have had their civil rights violated on multiple 
occasions. 

12. Upon  information  and belief, joinder  of all of these individuals is impracticable 
because  of  the  large  number  of  class members  and the  fact that  class rrsmbers  are likely 
dispersed over a large  geographical area, with  some members presently residing outside of 
Clatsop County  and this Judicial District.  Furthermore, upon information and belief, many 
members of the class are low-income persons, may not speak English, and likely would have 
great difficulty in pursuing their rights individually. 
13. Common questions of law and fact exist as to all members of the Class, in that they 
all had their right to be free from unreasonable searches violated by Defendants' conducting strip 
searches  absent  particularized  suspicion.  All  members  of  the  class  were  charged  with 
misdemeanors or violations when placed into the custody of the Clatsop County Jail, and all 
were illegally strip searched in violation of the clearly established law in this judicial circuit. 
14. Plaintiffs claims are typical of the claims of the members of the Class.  Plaintiff and 
all members of the class sustained damages arising out of Defendants' course of conduct.  The 
harms suffered by the Plaintiff are typical of the harms suffered by the class members. 
15. The representative Plaintiff has the requisite personal interest in the outcome of this 
action and will fairly and adequately protect the interests of the Class.  Plaintiff has no interests 
that are (adverset o the interests of the members of the Class. 
16. Plaintiff  has  retained counsel who has  substantial experience and  success  in the 
prosecution of civil rights litigation. 
17. Counsel for Plaintiff knows of no conflicts among members of the class, or between 
counsel and members of the class. 
118. This action, in part, seeks declaratory and injunctive relief.  As such, the Plaintiff 
seeks c1,ass certification under Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(2), in that all class members were subject to 

the same policy requiring the illegal strip searches of individuals charged with misdemeanor or 
minor crimes and placed into the custody of the Clatsop County Jail.  In short, the County of 
Clatsop, the Clatsop County Sheriffs Department, the Policy Making Defendants and Clatsop 
County Corrections Officers acted on grounds generally applicable to all class members. 
19. In addition to certification under Rule 23(b)(2), and in the alternative, Plaintiff seeks 
certification under Rule 23(b)(3). 
20. Common  questions  of  law  and  fact  exist  as to  all  members  of  the  Class,  and 
predominate  over  any  questions  that  affect  only  individual  members of the  Class.  These 
common questions of law and fact include, without limitation, the common and predominate 
question of whether the Defendants' written and/or de facto policylpractice of strip searching all 
individuals charged with misdemeanors or minor crimes and committed to the Clatsop County 
Jail is a violation of the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution, 
and whether such a written and/or de facto policy existed during the class period. 
211. A  class  action  is  superior to  other  available  methods  for  the  fair  and  efficient 
adjudication of this controversy, since joinder  of all of the individual members of the class is 
impracticable given the large number of class members and the fact that they are dispersed over a 
large geographical area.  Furthermore, the expense and burden of individual litigation would 
make it difficult or impossible for individual members of the class to redress the wrongs done to 
them.  The cost to the federal court system of adjudicating thousands of individual cases would 
be enormous.  Individualized litigation would also magnify the delay and expensc to all parties 
and the court system.  By contrast, the conduct of this action as a class action in this District 
presents far fewer management difficulties, conserves the resources of the parties and the court 
system, and protects the rights of each member of the Class. 

22. Upon  information  and belief,  there  are no  other  actions pending to  address the 
Defendaints'  flagrant violation of the civil rights of thousands of individuals, even though the 
Defenda:nts have maintained their illegal strip search regimen for the past several years. 
23. In the alternative to certification under Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(3), Plaintiff also seeks 
partial certification under Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(c)(4). 

FACTS 
Facts Applicable to the Class Generally 
24. The Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution prohibits  state officials, 
such as tlne Policy Making Defendants in this action and the Corrections Officers they supervise, 
from performing strip searches of arrestees who have been charged with misdemeanors or other 
minor crimes unless the officer has reasonable suspicion to believe that the arrestee is concealing 
a weapon or contraband. 
25. Upon information and belief, the County of Clatsop, the Clatsop County Sheriffs 
Department and the Policy Making Defendants have instituted a written and/or de jacto  policy, 
custom or practice of strip searching all individuals who enter the custody of the Clatsop County 
Jail (by forcing them to remove their clothing for a visual inspection of their bodies and/or 
forcing lhem to  submit to a visual inspection of their body cavities) and are placed into jail 
clothing, regardless of the nature of their charged crime and without the presence of reasonable 
suspicion to believe that the individual was concealing a weapon or contraband. For purposes of 
this Complaint, strip and visual cavity searches are collectively referred to as "strip searches." 
26. The County of Clatsop, the Clatsop County Sheriffs Department, and the Policy 
Making Defendants know that they may not institute, enforce or permit enforcement of a policy 
or  practice  of  conducting  strip  searches without  particularized,  reasonable  suspicion.  This 
judicial circuit has stated repeatedly that state officials may not strip search individuals charged 
with misdemeanors or violations absent particularized, reasonable suspicion, with this principle 
being clearly established in Kennedy v. Los Angeles P. D., 901 F2d 702, 7 11 , (9thC  ir. 1990). 

27. The  Defendants'  written  andlor  de facto policy,  practice  and  custom  mandating 
wholesalle  strip  searches of  all misdemeanor  and violation  arrestees has been  promulgated, 
effectualed and/or enforced in bad faith and contrary to clearly established law. 
28. Reasonable suspicion to conduct a strip search may only emanate from the particular 
circumstances antecedent to the search, such as the nature of the crime charged, the particular 
characteristics of the arrestees, andlor the circumstances of the arrest. 
2:9. Upon information and belief, the County of Clatsop, the Clatsop County Sheriffs 
Department and Policy Making Defendants have promulgated, implemented, enforced, andlor 
failed to  rectify  a written  andlor de facto policy,  practice  or  custom of  strip  searching all 
individuals placed  into the custody of the Clatsop County Jail and placed into jail  clothing 
without any requirement of reasonable suspicion, or indeed suspicion of any sort.  This written 
and/or de facto policy made the strip searching of pre-trial detainees routine; neither the nature of 
the offense charged, the characteristics of the arrestee, nor the circumstances of a particular arrest 
were relevant to the enforcement of the policy, practice and custom of routine strip searches. 
30. Pursuant to this written and/or de facto policy, each member of the Class, including 
the named Plaintiff, was the victim of a routine strip search upon their entry into the Clatsop 
County Jail.  These searches were conducted without inquiry into or establishment of reasonable 
suspicion, and in fact were not supported by reasonable suspicion.  Strip searches are conducted 
for  individuals  arrested  for,  among  other  innocuous  offenses,  Driving  While  Intoxicated, 
Harassment and Trespassing. 
3 1. As a direct and proximate result of the unlawful strip search conducted pursuant to 
this written and/or de jucto policy, the victims of the unlawful strip searches - each member of 

the  class,  including  the  named  Plaintiff  - has  suffered  or  will  suffer  psychological  pain, 
humiliatiion, suffering and mental anguish. 
Facts Applicable to the Named Plaintiff Rollins (Clatsop County) 
32. Mr. Darrell Rollins's experience is representative of the class at large.  On November 
20, 2005., Mr. Rollins was strip and cavity searched in the Clatsop County Jail. 
3 3. Mr. Rollins was moved into a shower area in the Clatsop County Jail and ordered to 
disrobe.  As a Corrections Officer watched, Mr. Rollins removed all of his clothing, including his 
underpants. 
34. A Corrections Officer then instructed Mr. Rollins to lift his testicles, turn around, 
bend at the waist, spread the lobes of his buttocks and squat while coughing, with the Corrections 
Officer conducting a visual inspection of Mr. Rollins' genitals and rectal cavity.  Mr. Rollins was 
then provided with a jail uniform after taking a shower. 
35. On this particular occasion, there was no reasonable suspicion to believe that Mr. 
Rollins was concealing a weapon or other contraband.  Indeed, no inquiry was made of Mr. 
Rollins that could have given rise to the requisite reasonable suspicion. 
36. As a direct and proximate result of the unlawful strip search conducted pursuant to 
County and Sheriffs Department policy, practice and custom, Mr. Rollins has suffered and 
continues to suffer psychological pain, humiliation, suffering and mental anguish. 

CAUSES OF ACTION 
AS AND FOR A FIRST CAUSE OF ACTION AGAINST ALL DEFENDANTS 
Violation of Constitutional Rights Under Color of State Law 
-- 
Unreasonable Search and Failure to Implement Municipal Policies to Avoid 
Constitutional Deprivations Under of Color of State Law -- 
37. Plaintiff incorporates by reference and realleges each and every allegation stated in 
paragraplhs 1 through 37. 
38. The  Fourth  Amendment of the United  States Constitution protects  citizens from 
unreasonable searches by law enforcement officers, and prohibits officers from conducting strip 
searches of  individuals  arrested for  misdemeanors  or  violations  absent  some particularized 
suspicion that the individual in question has either contraband or weapons. 
39. The actions of Defendants detailed above violated Plaintiffs rights under the United 
States  Constitution.  Simply  put,  it  was  not  objectively  reasonable  for  Clatsop  County 
Corrections  Officers to  strip  search Plaintiff  and class members  based  on their  arrests  for 
misdemeanor/violation charges.  It was also not objectively reasonable for the Policy Making 
Defendants to orderldirect Clatsop County Corrections Officers to conduct such searches. 
40. These strip searches were conducted pursuant to the policy, custom or practice of the 
County of Clatsop and the Clatsop County Sheriffs Department.  As such, the County of Clatsop 
is directly liable for the damages of the named Plaintiff and members of the Class. 
4.1. Upon  information  and  belief,  Sheriff Bergin  is  responsible  for  establishing  the 
policies  and  procedures  to  be  utilized  in the  operation  of  the  Clatsop  County  Jail,  and  is 
responsible for the implementation of the strip search policy questioned in this lawsuit.  As such, 
Roberts is individually responsible for the damages of the named Plaintiff and members of the 
Class. 

42. Sheriff  Bergin  knew  that  strip  search  policy  was  illegal,  and  acted  willfully, 
knowing,ly. and with  specific intent to  deprive Plaintiff  and members of the Class of their 
Constitutional rights. 
43. This conduct on the part of all Defendants represents a violation of 42 U.S.C. § 1983, 
given that their actions were undertaken under color of state law. 
4.4. As a direct and proximate result of the unconstitutional acts described above, Plaintiff 
and members of the proposed class have been irreparably injured. 

AS AND FOR A SECOND CAUSE OF ACTION AGAINST ALL DEFENDANTS 
--  -- 
Demand for Declaratory Judgment 
45. Plaintiff incorporates by reference and realleges each and every allegation stated in 
paragraphs 1 through 44. 
46. The policy, custom and practice of the Clatsop County Sheriffs Department, the 
County of Clatsop and the Policy Making Defendants is clearly unconstitutional, in that these 
entities and individuals are directinglconducting the strip searches of all individuals placed into 
the Clats'op County Jail without any particularized suspicion that the individuals in question have 
either contraband or weapons. 
47. Plaintiff  and  members  of  the  Class  request  that  this  Court  issue  a  declaratory 
judgment, and that it declare the strip search policy of the County of Clatsop and the Clatsop 
County Sheriffs Department to be unconstitutional. 
AS AND FOR A THIRD CAUSE OF ACTION AGAINST ALL DEFENDANTS 
--  -- 
Demand for Preliminary and Permanent Injunction 
4.8. Plaintiff incorporates by reference and realleges each and every allegation stated in 
paragraphs 1 through 48. 
4.9. The policy, custom and practice of the Clatsop County Sheriffs Department, the 
County of Clatsop and the Policy Making Defendants is clearly unconstitutional, in that these 
entities and individuals are directinglconducting the strip searches of all individuals placed into 
the Clatsop County Jail without any particularized suspicion that the individuals in question have 
either contraband or weapons. 

50. Upon information and belief, this policy is currently in place at the Clatsop County 
Jail, with new and/or prospective members of the Class being subjected to the harms that have 
already been inflicted upon the named Plaintiff. 
5 1. The continuing pattern of strip searching individuals charged with minor crimes will 
cause irreparable harm to the new and/or prospective members of the Class, an adequate remedy 
for which does not exist at law. 
52. Plaintiff  demands  that  the  County  of  Clatsop,  the  Clatsop  County  Sheriffs 
Department,  the  Policy  Making  Defendants  and  Clatsop  County  Corrections  Officers 
immedialtely desist  from strip searching  individuals placed  into the  custody  of the  Clatsop 
County Jail  absent  any particularized  suspicion that the  individuals in  question have  either 
contraband or weapons, and seek both a preliminary and permanent injunction from this Court 
ordering as much. 

DEMAND FOR PUNITIVE DAMAGES 
53. The actions of the Individual Defendants detailed herein are outrageous, in that they 
continue to propagate an illegal strip search policy even though they know for a fact that their 
actions are unconstitutional. 
54. It is clear that the Policy Making Defendants, the County of Clatsop and the Clatsop 
County Sheriffs Department have no respect for the civil rights of individual citizens or for the 
rule of law.  Consequently, an award of punitive damages is necessary to punish the Policy 
Making Defendants, and to send a message to them that the requirements of the United States 
Constitution also apply to government officials in Clatsop County. 
DEMAND FOR TRIAL BY JURY 
55. The Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury. 
PRAYER FOR RELIEF 
WHEREFORE, Plaintiff Darrell Rollins, on behalf of himself and on behalf of a class of 
others similarly situated, request that this Honorable Court grant him the following relief: 
A.  An order certifying this action as a class action pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 23. 
B.  A judgment against all Defendants, jointly and severally on Plaintiffs First Cause of 
Action detailed herein,  awarding Compensatory Damages to  each named Plaintiff  and each 
member of the proposed class in an amount to be determined by a Jury and/or the Court on both 
an individual and a class wide basis. 
C.  A  judgment  against  Defendant  Bergin  on  Plaintiffs  First  Cause  of  Action  for 
$1,000,000.00 in punitive damages. 

D.  A declaratory judgment against all Defendants declaring the County of Clatsop and 
the Clatslop County Sheriffs Department's policy, practice and custom of strip and visual cavity 
searching all detainees entering the Clatsop County Jail, regardless of the crime charged or 
suspicion of contraband, to be unconstitutional and improper. 
E.  A preliminary and permanent injunction enjoining Defendants from continuing to 
strip and visual cavity search individuals charged with misdemeanors or minor crimes absent 
particularized,  reasonable  suspicion  that  the  arrestee  subjected  to  the  search  is  concealing 
weapons or other contraband. 
F.  A monetary award for attorney's  fees and the costs of this action, pursuant to 42 
U.S.C. 5 1988 and Fed. R. Civ. P. 23 
I

INTRODUCTION 
 
  This is a class action brought to redress the deprivation by Defendants of rights secured 
to the Plaintiffs and proposed Class by the United States Constitution and the laws of the United 
States of America.  For at least the past several years, the Clatsop County Sheriff’s Department 
has had a policy of strip-searching all individuals who enter the Clatsop County Jail and are 
placed in jail clothing, regardless of the crime upon which they are charged.  Upon information 
AMENDED COMPLAINT  1 

Case 3:07-cv-01678-KI    Document 16    Filed 09/18/08    Page 2 of 23    Page ID#: 68
and belief, this policy is, in part, derived from the written procedures of the Clatsop County 
Sheriff’s  Department,  and  was  promulgated  by  senior  Department  officials;  specifically, 
Defendant Tom Bergin. 
It has been well established in this judicial circuit for many years that individuals charged 
with misdemeanors or violations cannot be strip-searched absent particularized suspicion that 
they possess weapons or contraband.  In fact, several judges in this Judicial District, as well as 
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, have recently held that blanket strip 
search policies/practices like those in dispute in this case are unconstitutional.  In short, the 
policy of Clatsop County and the Clatsop County Sheriff’s Department of forcing those charged 
with minor crimes to undergo the indignities of a strip search upon entry into the Clatsop County 
Jail is not only clearly illegal, but is degrading, insensitive and unnecessary.  
  Darrell  Rollins,  Debbi  Davis,  Tyler  King,  Noel  Leroux,  David  Menken,  Stephen 
Schwanbeck,  and Brandi Stephens bring this action on behalf of themselves,  and on behalf of a 
class of thousands of others who were strip searched after being charged with petty crimes, to 
vindicate the clear and unnecessary violation of his civil rights and those of the class members he 
proposes to represent. Mr. Rollins was taken in on allegations of Resisting Arrest. Mr. Rollins 
was transported to the Clatsop County Jail and was subjected to a strip search, in violation of his 
right  against  unreasonable  searches  under  the  Fourth  Amendment  of  the  United  States 
Constitution.  He seeks monetary damages for himself and each member of the proposed class, a 
declaration  that  the  Sheriff’s  Department’s  policies/practices  are  unconstitutional,  and  an 
injunction  precluding  Clatsop  County  and  the  Clatsop  County  Sheriff’s  Department  from 
continuing to violate the rights of those placed into their custody.  With this as a background, 
Plaintiff Darrell Rollins, et al through counsel, hereby complains as follows: 
AMENDED COMPLAINT  2 

Case 3:07-cv-01678-KI    Document 16    Filed 09/18/08    Page 3 of 23    Page ID#: 69
 
JURISDICTION 
1.  This Court has jurisdiction over this action under the provisions of 28 U.S.C. §§ 
1331, 1341 & 1343 because it is filed to obtain compensatory damages, punitive damages, and 
injunctive relief for the deprivation, under color of state law, of the rights of citizens of the 
United States secured by the Constitution and federal law pursuant to 42 U.S.C. §§ 1981 & 1983.  
This Court also has jurisdiction over this action under the provisions of 28 U.S.C. § 2201, as it is 
filed  to  obtain  declaratory relief  relative  to  the  Constitutionality  of  the  policies  of  a local 
government. 
2.  Venue is proper under 28 U.S.C. § 1391(e)(2) because the events giving rise to 
Plaintiff’s claims and those of proposed class members occurred in this judicial district. 
 
PARTIES 
3.  Plaintiff Darrell Rollins (“Rollins”) resides in Wahkiakum County, Oregon.  On or 
about November 20, 2005, he was housed at the Clatsop County Jail for allegation of Resisting 
Arrest.  
4.  Plaintiff Debbi Davis (“Davis”) resides in  Clatsop County, Oregon.  On or about 
April  18,  2008,  she  was  housed  at  the  Clatsop  County  Jail  for  allegation  of  Hindering 
Prosecution. 
5.  Plaintiff Brandi Stephens (“Stephens”) resides in Clatsop County, Oregon.  On or 
about March 17, 2006, she was housed at the Clatsop County Jail for being a fugitive on DUI 
and Theft charges. 
 
AMENDED COMPLAINT  3 

Case 3:07-cv-01678-KI    Document 16    Filed 09/18/08    Page 4 of 23    Page ID#: 70
6.  Plaintiff Tyler King (“King”) resides in Snohomish County, Washington.  On or 
about June 16, 2006, he was housed at the Clatsop County Jail for allegation of a fugitive 
warrant for Assault 2 and Endangering Children. 
7.  Plaintiff Noel Leroux (“Leroux”) resides inClatsop County, Oregon.  On or about 
January 19, 2008, he was housed at the Clatsop County Jail for allegation of DUI. 
8.  Plaintiff David Menken (“Menken”) resides in Clatsop County, Oregon.  On or about 
February t, 2006, he was housed at the Clatsop County Jail for allegation of Resisting Arrest.  
9.  Plaintiff Stephen Schwanbeck (“Schwanbeck”) resides in Clatsop County, Oregon.  
On or about September 21, 2006, he was housed at the Clatsop County Jail for allegation of  
DUI.  
10. Defendant Clatsop County (the “County”) is a county government organized and 
existing under the laws of the State of Oregon.  At all times relevant hereto, the County, acting 
through  its  Sheriff’s  Department,  was  responsible  for  the  policies,  practices,  supervision, 
implementation  and  conduct  of  all  matters  pertaining  to  the  Clatsop  County  Jail  and  was 
responsible for the appointment, training, supervision and conduct of all Sheriff’s Department 
personnel, including those working in the Clatsop County Jail.  In addition, at all relevant times, 
the County was responsible for enforcing the rules of the Clatsop County Jail, and for ensuring 
that Sheriff’s Department personnel employed in the Jail obey the Constitution and laws of the 
United States and of the State of Oregon. 
11. The Clatsop County Sheriff’s Department (the “Sheriff’s Department”) is a County 
Sheriff’s Department organized and existing under the laws of the State of Oregon. At all times 
relevant hereto, the Sheriff’s Department was responsible for operating, organizing, overseeing 
and administering the Clatsop County Jail (“CTCJ”).  At all times relevant hereto, Defendant 
AMENDED COMPLAINT  4 

Case 3:07-cv-01678-KI    Document 16    Filed 09/18/08    Page 5 of 23    Page ID#: 71
Sheriff’s Department, together with Clatsop County was responsible for the polices, practices, 
supervision,  implementation  and  conduct  of  all  matters  pertaining  to  the  CTCJ,  and  was 
responsible for the appointment, training, supervision and conduct of all Sheriff’s Department 
personnel, including those working in the CTCJ.  In addition, at all times relevant hereto, 
Defendant Sheriff’s Department, together with Clatsop County, was responsible for enforcing 
the rules of the Clatsop County Jail,  and for ensuring that Sheriff’s Department personnel 
employed in the CTCJ obeyed the Constitution and laws of the United States and of the State of 
Oregon. 
12. Defendant Tom Bergin is the duly elected Sheriff of Clatsop County, and, as such, is 
a policy maker with respect to the treatment of pre-trial and other detainees over which the CTCJ 
exercises custodial or other control. Sheriff Bergin is made a Defendant in this action in both his 
individual and official capacities. 
13.   Sheriff Bergin will be referred to as the “Policy Making Defendant.” 
AMENDED COMPLAINT  5 

Case 3:07-cv-01678-KI    Document 16    Filed 09/18/08    Page 6 of 23    Page ID#: 72
CLASS ACTION ALLEGATIONS 
14. Plaintiff brings this action pursuant to Rules 23(b)(1), 23(b)(2) and 23(b)(3) of the 
Federal Rules of Civil Procedure on behalf of themselves and a class of similarly situated 
individuals who were charged with misdemeanors or minor crimes and were strip searched upon 
their entry into the Clatsop County Jail. 
15. The class that Plaintiffs seek to represent is defined as follows: 
All persons who have been or will be placed into the custody of the Clatsop 
County Jail after being charged with misdemeanors, violations, violations of 
probation or parole, traffic infractions, civil commitments or other minor 
crimes and were or will be strip searched upon their entry into the Clatsop 
County Jail pursuant to the policy, custom and practice of the Clatsop 
County  Sheriff’s  Department  and  Clatsop  County.    The  class  period 
commences on November 8, 2005 and extends to the date on which the 
Clatsop County Sheriff’s Department  and/or the County of Clatsop are 
enjoined from, or otherwise cease, enforcing their unconstitutional policy, 
practice  and  custom  of  conducting  strip  searches  absent  reasonable 
suspicion.  Specifically excluded from the class are Defendants and any and 
all  of  their  respective  affiliates,  legal  representatives,  heirs,  successors, 
employees or assignees.   
 
16. This action has been brought and may properly be maintained as a class action under 
Federal law and satisfies the numerosity, commonality, typicality and adequacy requirements for 
maintaining a class action under Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a). 
17. The members of the class are so numerous as to render joinder impracticable.  Upon 
information and belief, there are hundreds of people arrested for misdemeanors and violations 
who are placed into the custody of the Clatsop County Jail every month – all of whom are 
members of the proposed class.  Upon information and belief, the size of the proposed class 
totals at least 1,000 individuals, some of whom have had their civil rights violated on multiple 
occasions. 
AMENDED COMPLAINT  6 

Case 3:07-cv-01678-KI    Document 16    Filed 09/18/08    Page 7 of 23    Page ID#: 73
18. Upon information and belief, joinder of all of these individuals is impracticable 
because of the large number of class members and the fact that class members are likely 
dispersed over a large geographical area, with some members presently residing outside of 
Clatsop County and this Judicial District.  Furthermore, upon information and belief, many 
members of the class are low-income persons, may not speak English, and likely would have 
great difficulty in pursuing their rights individually. 
19. Common questions of law and fact exist as to all members of the Class, in that they 
all had their right to be free from unreasonable searches violated by Defendants’ conducting strip 
searches  absent  particularized  suspicion.    All  members  of  the  class  were  charged  with 
misdemeanors or violations when placed into the custody of the Clatsop County Jail, and all 
were illegally strip searched in violation of the clearly established law in this judicial circuit. 
20. Plaintiff’s claims are typical of the claims of the members of the Class.  Plaintiff and 
all members of the class sustained damages arising out of Defendants’ course of conduct.  The 
harms suffered by the Plaintiff are typical of the harms suffered by the class members. 
21. The representative Plaintiff has the requisite personal interest in the outcome of this 
action and will fairly and adequately protect the interests of the Class.  Plaintiff has no interests 
that are adverse to the interests of the members of the Class. 
22. Plaintiff has retained counsel who has  substantial experience and success in the 
prosecution of civil rights litigation.  
23. Counsel for Plaintiff knows of no conflicts among members of the class, or between 
counsel and members of the class. 
24. This action, in part, seeks declaratory and injunctive relief.  As such, the Plaintiff 
seeks class certification under Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(2), in that all class members were subject to 
AMENDED COMPLAINT  7 

Case 3:07-cv-01678-KI    Document 16    Filed 09/18/08    Page 8 of 23    Page ID#: 74
the same policy requiring the illegal strip searches of individuals charged with misdemeanor or 
minor crimes and placed into the custody of the Clatsop County Jail.  In short, the County of 
Clatsop, the Clatsop County Sheriff’s Department, the Policy Making Defendants and Clatsop  
County Corrections Officers acted on grounds generally applicable to all class members. 
25. In addition to certification under Rule 23(b)(2), and in the alternative, Plaintiff seeks 
certification under Rule 23(b)(3).   
26. Common  questions  of  law  and  fact  exist  as  to  all  members  of  the  Class,  and 
predominate  over  any  questions  that  affect  only  individual  members  of  the  Class.    These 
common questions of law and fact include, without limitation, the common and predominate 
question of whether the Defendants’ written and/or de facto policy/practice of strip searching all 
individuals charged with misdemeanors or minor crimes and committed to the Clatsop County 
Jail is a violation of the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution, 
and whether such a written and/or de facto policy existed during the class period. 
27. A  class  action  is  superior  to  other  available  methods  for  the  fair  and  efficient 
adjudication of this controversy, since joinder of all of the individual members of the class is 
impracticable given the large number of class members and the fact that they are dispersed over a 
large geographical area.  Furthermore, the expense and burden of individual litigation would 
make it difficult or impossible for individual members of the class to redress the wrongs done to 
them.  The cost to the federal court system of adjudicating thousands of individual cases would 
be enormous.  Individualized litigation would also magnify the delay and expense to all parties 
and the court system.  By contrast, the conduct of this action as a class action in this District 
presents far fewer management difficulties, conserves the resources of the parties and the court 
system, and protects the rights of each member of the Class. 
AMENDED COMPLAINT  8 

Case 3:07-cv-01678-KI    Document 16    Filed 09/18/08    Page 9 of 23    Page ID#: 75
28. Upon  information  and  belief,  there  are  no  other  actions  pending  to  address  the 
Defendants’ flagrant violation of the civil rights of thousands of individuals, even though the 
Defendants have maintained their illegal strip search regimen for the past several years. 
29. In the alternative to certification under Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(3), Plaintiffs also seek 
partial certification under Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(c)(4). 
 
AMENDED COMPLAINT  9 

Case 3:07-cv-01678-KI    Document 16    Filed 09/18/08    Page 10 of 23    Page ID#: 76
FACTS 
Facts Applicable to the Class Generally 
30. The Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution prohibits state officials, 
such as the Policy Making Defendants in this action and the Corrections Officers they supervise, 
from performing strip searches of arrestees who have been charged with misdemeanors or other 
minor crimes unless the officer has reasonable suspicion to believe that the arrestee is concealing 
a weapon or contraband. 
31. Upon information and belief, the County of Clatsop, the Clatsop County Sheriff’s 
Department and the Policy Making Defendants have instituted a written and/or de facto policy, 
custom or practice of strip searching all individuals who enter the custody of the Clatsop County 
Jail (by forcing them to remove their clothing for a visual inspection of their bodies and/or 
forcing them to submit to a visual inspection of their body cavities) and are placed into jail 
clothing, regardless of the nature of their charged crime and without the presence of reasonable 
suspicion to believe that the individual was concealing a weapon or contraband. For purposes of 
this Complaint, strip and visual cavity searches are collectively referred to as “strip searches.” 
32. The County of Clatsop, the Clatsop County Sheriff’s Department, and the Policy 
Making Defendants know that they may not institute, enforce or permit enforcement of a policy 
or  practice  of  conducting  strip  searches  without  particularized, reasonable  suspicion.    This 
judicial circuit has stated repeatedly that state officials may not strip search individuals charged 
with misdemeanors or violations absent particularized, reasonable suspicion, with this principle 
being clearly established in Kennedy v. Los Angeles P.D., 901 F2d 702, 711, (9th Cir. 1990). 
AMENDED COMPLAINT  10 

Case 3:07-cv-01678-KI    Document 16    Filed 09/18/08    Page 11 of 23    Page ID#: 77
33. The  Defendants’  written  and/or  de  facto  policy,  practice  and  custom  mandating 
wholesale  strip searches of  all misdemeanor and violation arrestees has been promulgated, 
effectuated and/or enforced in bad faith and contrary to clearly established law. 
34. Reasonable suspicion to conduct a strip search may only emanate from the particular 
circumstances antecedent to the search, such as the nature of the crime charged, the particular 
characteristics of the arrestees, and/or the circumstances of the arrest. 
35. Upon information and belief, the County of Clatsop, the Clatsop County Sheriff’s 
Department and Policy Making Defendants have promulgated, implemented, enforced, and/or 
failed to rectify a written and/or de facto policy, practice or custom of strip searching all 
individuals placed into the custody of the Clatsop County Jail and placed into jail clothing 
without any requirement of reasonable suspicion, or indeed suspicion of any sort.  This written 
and/or de facto policy made the strip searching of pre-trial detainees routine; neither the nature of 
the offense charged, the characteristics of the arrestee, nor the circumstances of a particular arrest 
were relevant to the enforcement of the policy, practice and custom of routine strip searches.   
36. Pursuant to this written and/or de facto policy, each member of the Class, including 
the named Plaintiff, was the victim of a routine strip search upon their entry into the Clatsop 
County Jail.  These searches were conducted without inquiry into or establishment of reasonable 
suspicion, and in fact were not supported by reasonable suspicion.  Strip searches are conducted 
for  individuals  arrested  for,  among  other  innocuous  offenses,  Driving  While  Intoxicated, 
Harassment and Trespassing. 
37. As a direct and proximate result of the unlawful strip search conducted pursuant to 
this written and/or de facto policy, the victims of the unlawful strip searches – each member of 
AMENDED COMPLAINT  11 

Case 3:07-cv-01678-KI    Document 16    Filed 09/18/08    Page 12 of 23    Page ID#: 78
the  class,  including  the  named  Plaintiffs  –  has  suffered  or  will  suffer  psychological  pain, 
humiliation, suffering and mental anguish. 
 
Facts Applicable to the Named Plaintiff Rollins  
38. Mr. Darrell Rollins’s experience is representative of the class at large.  On November 
20, 2005,  Mr. Rollins was strip and cavity searched in the Clatsop County Jail. 
39. Mr. Rollins was moved into a shower area in the Clatsop County Jail and ordered to 
disrobe.  As a Corrections Officer watched, Mr. Rollins removed all of his clothing, including his 
underpants.   
40.  A Corrections Officer then instructed Mr. Rollins to lift his testicles, turn around, 
bend at the waist, spread the lobes of his buttocks and squat while coughing, with the Corrections 
Officer conducting a visual inspection of Mr. Rollins’ genitals and rectal cavity.  Mr. Rollins was 
then provided with a jail uniform after taking a shower.  
41. On this particular occasion, there was no reasonable suspicion to believe that Mr. 
Rollins was concealing a weapon or other contraband.  Indeed, no inquiry was made of Mr. 
Rollins that could have given rise to the requisite reasonable suspicion.   
42. As a direct and proximate result of the unlawful strip search conducted pursuant to 
County and Sheriff’s Department policy, practice and custom, Mr. Rollins has suffered and 
continues to suffer psychological pain, humiliation, suffering and mental anguish. 
 
Facts Applicable to the Named Plaintiff King 
43. Mr. Tyler King’s experience is representative of the class at large.  On June 16, 2006,   
Mr. Tyler King was strip and cavity searched in the Clatsop County Jail.

44. Mr. Tyler King was moved into a shower area in the Clatsop County Jail and ordered 
to disrobe.  As a Corrections Officer watched, Mr. Tyler King removed all of his clothing,

45.  A Corrections Officer then instructed Mr. Tyler King to lift his testicles, turn around,

Facts Applicable to the Named Plaintiff Leroux 
48. Mr. Tyler King’s experience is representative of the class at large.  On January 19, 
2008,   Mr.  Noel Leroux was strip and cavity searched in the Clatsop County Jail. 
49. Mr. Noel Leroux was moved into a shower area in the Clatsop County Jail and 
ordered to disrobe.  As a Corrections Officer watched, Mr. Noel Leroux removed all of his 
clothing, including his underpants.   
50.  A Corrections Officer then instructed Mr. Noel Leroux to lift his testicles, turn 
around, bend at the waist, spread the lobes of his buttocks and squat while coughing, with the 
AMENDED COMPLAINT  13 

Case 3:07-cv-01678-KI    Document 16    Filed 09/18/08    Page 14 of 23    Page ID#: 80
Corrections Officer conducting a visual inspection of Mr. Noel Leroux’s genitals and rectal 
cavity.  Mr. Noel Leroux was then provided with a jail uniform after taking a shower.  
51. On this particular occasion, there was no reasonable suspicion to believe that Mr. 
Noel Leroux was concealing a weapon or other contraband.  Indeed, no inquiry was made of Mr.

52. As a direct and proximate result of the unlawful strip search conducted pursuant to 
County and Sheriff’s Department policy, practice and custom, Mr. Noel Leroux has suffered and

Facts Applicable to the Named Plaintiff Schwanbeck 
53. Mr. Stephen Schwanbeck’s experience is representative of the class at large.  On 
September 21, 2006,   Mr. Stephen Schwanbeck was strip and cavity searched in the Clatsop 
County Jail. 
54. Mr. Stephen Schwanbeck was moved into a shower area in the Clatsop County Jail 
and ordered to disrobe.  As a Corrections Officer watched, Mr. Stephen Schwanbeck removed all 
of his clothing, including his underpants.   
55.  A Corrections Officer then instructed Mr. Stephen Schwanbeck to lift his testicles, 
turn around, bend at the waist, spread the lobes of his buttocks and squat while coughing, with 
the Corrections Officer conducting a visual inspection of Mr. Stephen Schwanbeck’s genitals 
and rectal cavity.  Mr. Stephen Schwanbeck was then provided with a jail uniform after taking a 
shower.  
AMENDED COMPLAINT  14 

Case 3:07-cv-01678-KI    Document 16    Filed 09/18/08    Page 15 of 23    Page ID#: 81
56. On this particular occasion, there was no reasonable suspicion to believe that Mr. 
Stephen Schwanbeck was concealing a weapon or other contraband.  Indeed, no inquiry was 
made  of  Mr.  Stephen  Schwanbeck  that  could  have  given  rise  to  the  requisite  reasonable 
suspicion.   
57. As a direct and proximate result of the unlawful strip search conducted pursuant to 
County and Sheriff’s Department policy, practice and custom, Mr. Stephen Schwanbeck has 
suffered and continues to suffer psychological pain, humiliation, suffering and mental anguish. 
 
Facts Applicable to the Named Plaintiff Menken 
58. Mr. David Menken’s experience is representative of the class at large.  On February 
7, 2006,   Mr. David Menken was strip and cavity searched in the Clatsop County Jail. 
59. Mr. David Menken was moved into a shower area in the Clatsop County Jail and 
ordered to disrobe.  As a Corrections Officer watched, Mr. David Menken removed all of his 
clothing, including his underpants.   
60.  A Corrections Officer then instructed Mr. David Menken to lift his testicles, turn 
around, bend at the waist, spread the lobes of his buttocks and squat while coughing, with the 
Corrections Officer conducting a visual inspection of Mr. David Menken’s genitals and rectal 
cavity.  Mr. David Menken was then provided with a jail uniform after taking a shower.  
61. On this particular occasion, there was no reasonable suspicion to believe that Mr. 
David Menken was concealing a weapon or other contraband.  Indeed, no inquiry was made of 
Mr. Stephen Schwanbeck that could have given rise to the requisite reasonable suspicion.   
AMENDED COMPLAINT  15 

Case 3:07-cv-01678-KI    Document 16    Filed 09/18/08    Page 16 of 23    Page ID#: 82
62. As a direct and proximate result of the unlawful strip search conducted pursuant to 
County and Sheriff’s Department policy, practice and custom, Mr. David Menken has suffered 
and continues to suffer psychological pain, humiliation, suffering and mental anguish. 
 
Facts Applicable to the Named Plaintiff Davis 
 
 
63.  Ms. Debbi Davis’ experience is representative of the class at large.  On April 18, 
2008, Ms. Debbi Davis was strip and cavity searched in the Clatsop County Jail. 
64. Ms. Debbi Davis was moved into a shower area in the Clatsop County Jail and 
ordered to disrobe.  As a Corrections Officer watched, Ms. Debbi Davis removed all of her 
clothing, including her underpants.  
65. On the above-mentioned occasion, Debbi Davis was moved into a shower area in the

66.  On this occasion, a Corrections Officer then instructed Ms. Debbi Davis  
to turn around, bend at the waist, spread the lobes of her buttocks and squat while coughing, with

68. As a direct and proximate result of the unlawful strip search conducted pursuant to 
County and Sheriff’s Department policy, practice and custom, Ms. Debbi Davis has suffered and 
continues to suffer psychological pain, humiliation, suffering and mental anguish. 
Facts Applicable to the Named Plaintiff Stephens 
 
 
69.  Ms. Brandi Stephens’ experience is representative of the class at large.  On March 
17, 2006, Ms. Brandi Stephens’ was strip and cavity searched in the Clatsop County Jail. 
70. Ms. Brandi Stephens’ was moved into a shower area in the Clatsop County Jail and 
ordered to disrobe.  As a Corrections Officer watched, Ms. Brandi Stephens removed all of her

71. On the above-mentioned occasion, Brandi Stephens’ was moved into a shower area in 
the Clatsop County Jail and ordered to disrobe.  As a Corrections Officer watched, Ms. Brandi 
Stephens’ removed all of her clothing, including her underpants.   
72.  On this occasion, a Corrections Officer then instructed Ms. Brandi Stephens  
to turn around, bend at the waist, spread the lobes of her buttocks and squat while coughing, with 
the Corrections Officer conducting a visual inspection of Ms. Brandi Stephens’ genitals and 
rectal cavity. Ms. Brandi Stephens was then provided with a jail uniform. 
73. On each occasion, there was no reasonable suspicion to believe that Ms. Brandi 
Stephens’ was concealing a weapon or other contraband.  Indeed, no inquiry was made of Ms. 
Brandi Stephens that could have given rise to the requisite reasonable suspicion.   
74. As a direct and proximate result of the unlawful strip search conducted pursuant to 
County and Sheriff’s Department policy, practice and custom, Ms. Brandi Stephens has suffered

AMENDED COMPLAINT  17 

Case 3:07-cv-01678-KI    Document 16    Filed 09/18/08    Page 18 of 23    Page ID#: 84
 
AS AND FOR A FIRST CAUSE OF ACTION AGAINST ALL DEFENDANTS 
Violation of Constitutional Rights Under Color of State Law 
 
-- Unreasonable Search and Failure to Implement Municipal Policies to Avoid 
Constitutional Deprivations Under of Color of State Law -- 
 
75. Plaintiffs incorporate by reference and realleg each and every allegation stated in 
paragraphs 1 through 74. 
76. The Fourth Amendment of the United States  Constitution protects citizens from 
unreasonable searches by law enforcement officers, and prohibits officers from conducting strip 
searches  of  individuals  arrested  for  misdemeanors  or  violations  absent  some  particularized 
suspicion that the individual in question has either contraband or weapons. 
77. The actions of Defendants detailed above violated Plaintiff’s rights under the United 
States  Constitution.    Simply  put,  it  was  not  objectively  reasonable  for  Clatsop  County 
Corrections  Officers  to  strip  search  Plaintiff  and  class  members  based  on  their  arrests  for 
misdemeanor/violation charges.  It was also not objectively reasonable for the Policy Making 
Defendants to order/direct Clatsop County Corrections Officers to conduct such searches.   
78. These strip searches were conducted pursuant to the policy, custom or practice of the 
County of Clatsop and the Clatsop County Sheriff’s Department.  As such, the County of Clatsop 
is directly liable for the damages of the named Plaintiff and members of the Class. 
79. Upon  information  and  belief,  Sheriff  Bergin  is  responsible  for  establishing  the 
policies  and  procedures  to  be  utilized  in  the  operation  of  the  Clatsop  County  Jail,  and  is 
responsible for the implementation of the strip search policy questioned in this lawsuit.  As such, 
Roberts is individually responsible for the damages of the named Plaintiff and members of the 
Class.    
AMENDED COMPLAINT  18 

Case 3:07-cv-01678-KI    Document 16    Filed 09/18/08    Page 19 of 23    Page ID#: 85
80. Sheriff  Bergin  knew  that  strip  search  policy  was  illegal,  and  acted  willfully, 
knowingly, and with specific intent to deprive Plaintiff and members of the Class of their 
Constitutional rights. 
81. This conduct on the part of all Defendants represents a violation of 42 U.S.C. § 1983, 
given that their actions were undertaken under color of state law. 
82. As a direct and proximate result of the unconstitutional acts described above, Plaintiff 
and members of the proposed class have been irreparably injured. 
 
AMENDED COMPLAINT  19 

Case 3:07-cv-01678-KI    Document 16    Filed 09/18/08    Page 20 of 23    Page ID#: 86
AS AND FOR A SECOND CAUSE OF ACTION AGAINST ALL DEFENDANTS 
 
-- Demand for Declaratory Judgment -- 
 
83. Plaintiffs incorporate by reference and reallege each and every allegation stated in 
paragraphs 1 through 82. 
84. The policy, custom and practice of the Clatsop County Sheriff’s Department, the 
County of Clatsop and the Policy Making Defendants is clearly unconstitutional, in that these 
entities and individuals are directing/conducting the strip searches of all individuals placed into 
the Clatsop County Jail without any particularized suspicion that the individuals in question have 
either contraband or weapons. 
85. Plaintiff  and  members  of  the  Class  request  that  this  Court  issue  a  declaratory 
judgment, and that it declare the strip search policy of the County of Clatsop and the Clatsop 
County Sheriff’s Department to be unconstitutional. 
 
AS AND FOR A THIRD CAUSE OF ACTION AGAINST ALL DEFENDANTS 
-- Demand for Preliminary and Permanent Injunction -- 
86. Plaintiffs incorporate by reference and reallege each and every allegation stated in 
paragraphs 1 through 85. 
87. The policy, custom and practice of the Clatsop County Sheriff’s Department, the 
County of Clatsop and the Policy Making Defendants is clearly unconstitutional, in that these 
entities and individuals are directing/conducting the strip searches of all individuals placed into 
the Clatsop County Jail without any particularized suspicion that the individuals in question have 
either contraband or weapons. 
AMENDED COMPLAINT  20 

Case 3:07-cv-01678-KI    Document 16    Filed 09/18/08    Page 21 of 23    Page ID#: 87
88. Upon information and belief, this policy is currently in place at the Clatsop County 
Jail, with new and/or prospective members of the Class being subjected to the harms that have 
already been inflicted upon the named Plaintiff.   
89. The continuing pattern of strip searching individuals charged with minor crimes will 
cause irreparable harm to the new and/or prospective members of the Class, an adequate remedy 
for which does not exist at law. 
90. Plaintiff  demands  that  the  County  of  Clatsop,  the  Clatsop  County  Sheriff’s 
Department,  the  Policy  Making  Defendants  and  Clatsop  County  Corrections  Officers 
immediately desist from strip searching individuals placed into the custody of the  Clatsop 
County Jail absent  any particularized suspicion that the individuals in question have either 
contraband or weapons, and seek both a preliminary and permanent injunction from this Court 
ordering as much. 
 
 
 
AMENDED COMPLAINT  21 

Case 3:07-cv-01678-KI    Document 16    Filed 09/18/08    Page 22 of 23    Page ID#: 88
DEMAND FOR PUNITIVE DAMAGES 
91.  The actions of the Individual Defendants detailed herein are outrageous, in that they 
continue to propagate an illegal strip search policy even though they know for a fact that their 
actions are unconstitutional. 
92. It is clear that the Policy Making Defendants, the County of Clatsop and the Clatsop 
County Sheriff’s Department have no respect for the civil rights of individual citizens or for the 
rule of law.  Consequently, an award of punitive damages is necessary to punish the Policy 
Making Defendants, and to send a message to them that the requirements of the United States 
Constitution also apply to government officials in Clatsop County. 
 
DEMAND FOR TRIAL BY JURY 
93. The Plaintiffs hereby demand a trial by jury. 
 
PRAYER FOR RELIEF 
WHEREFORE, Plaintiffs Darrell Rollins et al, on behalf of themselves and on behalf of a 
class of others similarly situated, request that this Honorable Court grant them the following 
relief: 
A.  An order certifying this action as a class action pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 23. 
B.  A judgment against all Defendants, jointly and severally on Plaintiffs’ First Cause of 
Action detailed herein, awarding Compensatory Damages to each named Plaintiff and each 
member of the proposed class in an amount to be determined by a Jury and/or the Court on both 
an individual and a class wide basis.  
AMENDED COMPLAINT  22 

Case 3:07-cv-01678-KI    Document 16    Filed 09/18/08    Page 23 of 23    Page ID#: 89
C.  A  judgment  against  Defendant  Bergin  on  Plaintiff’s  First  Cause  of  Action  for 
$1,000,000.00 in punitive damages. 
D.  A declaratory judgment against all Defendants declaring the County of Clatsop and 
the Clatsop County Sheriff’s Department’s policy, practice and custom of strip and visual cavity 
searching all detainees entering the Clatsop County Jail, regardless of the crime charged or 
suspicion of contraband, to be unconstitutional and improper. 
E.  A preliminary and permanent injunction enjoining Defendants from continuing to 
strip and visual cavity search individuals charged with misdemeanors or minor crimes absent 
particularized,  reasonable  suspicion  that  the  arrestee  subjected  to  the  search  is  concealing 
weapons or other contraband. 
F.  A monetary award for attorney’s fees and the costs of this action, pursuant to 42 
U.S.C. § 1988 and Fed. R. Civ. P. 23 
 
 
 
Respectfully submitted by: 
             
            S//S 
            Leonard R. Berman 
 
Dated:  September 18, 2008      ______________________ 
            Leonard R. Berman, OSB # 96040 
ATTORNEY FOR PLAINTIFF AND THE 
PROPOSED CLASS 
 
 
 
AMENDED COMPLAINT  23
